name: Link
comment: dart-io.Link objects are references to filesystem links.

absolute.name: absolute
absolute.comment:
Returns a dart-io.Link instance whose path is the absolute path to this.

The absolute path is computed by prefixing a relative path with the current working directory, and returning an absolute path unchanged.

fromUri.name: fromUri
fromUri.comment:
Create a Lint object from a URI.

If dart-io.Link.Link-fromUri.uri cannot reference a link this throws dart-core.UnsupportedError.

create.name: create
create.comment:
Creates a symbolic link. Returns a Future<Link> that completes with the link when it has been created. If the link exists, the future will complete with an error.

If dart-io.Link.create.recursive is false, the default, the link is created only if all directories in its path exist. If dart-io.Link.create.recursive is true, all non-existing path components are created. The directories in the path of dart-io.Link.create.target are not affected, unless they are also in dart-io.Link.path.

On the Windows platform, this will only work with directories, and the target directory must exist. The link will be created as a Junction. Only absolute links will be created, and relative paths to the target will be converted to absolute paths by joining them with the path of the directory the link is contained in.

On other platforms, the posix symlink() call is used to make a symbolic link containing the string dart-io.Link.create.target. If dart-io.Link.create.target is a relative path, it will be interpreted relative to the directory containing the link.

createSync.name: createSync
createSync.comment:
Synchronously create the link. Calling dart-io.Link.createSync on an existing link will throw an exception.

If dart-io.Link.createSync.recursive is false, the default, the link is created only if all directories in its path exist. If dart-io.Link.createSync.recursive is true, all non-existing path components are created. The directories in the path of dart-io.Link.createSync.target are not affected, unless they are also in dart-io.Link.path.

On the Windows platform, this will only work with directories, and the target directory must exist. The link will be created as a Junction. Only absolute links will be created, and relative paths to the target will be converted to absolute paths.

On other platforms, the posix symlink() call is used to make a symbolic link containing the string dart-io.Link.createSync.target. If dart-io.Link.createSync.target is a relative path, it will be interpreted relative to the directory containing the link.

updateSync.name: updateSync
updateSync.comment:
Synchronously updates the link. Calling dart-io.Link.updateSync on a non-existing link will throw an exception.

On the Windows platform, this will only work with directories, and the target directory must exist.

update.name: update
update.comment:
Updates the link. Returns a Future<Link> that completes with the link when it has been updated. Calling dart-io.Link.update on a non-existing link will complete its returned future with an exception.

On the Windows platform, this will only work with directories, and the target directory must exist.

resolveSymbolicLinks.name: resolveSymbolicLinks
resolveSymbolicLinks.comment:
Resolves the path of a file system object relative to the current working directory, resolving all symbolic links on the path and resolving all '..' and '.' path segments. dart-io.Link.resolveSymbolicLinks returns a Future<String>

dart-io.Link.resolveSymbolicLinks uses the operating system's native filesystem api to resolve the path, using the realpath function on linux and Mac OS, and the GetFinalPathNameByHandle function on Windows. If the path does not point to an existing file system object, dart-io.Link.resolveSymbolicLinks completes the returned Future with an FileSystemException.

On Windows, symbolic links are resolved to their target before applying a '..' that follows, and on other platforms, the '..' is applied to the symbolic link without resolving it. The second behavior can be emulated on Windows by processing any '..' segments before calling dart-io.Link.resolveSymbolicLinks. One way of doing this is with the URI class: :new Uri.parse('.').resolveUri(new Uri.file(input)).toFilePath();, since resolve removes '..' segments.

resolveSymbolicLinksSync.name: resolveSymbolicLinksSync
resolveSymbolicLinksSync.comment:
Resolves the path of a file system object relative to the current working directory, resolving all symbolic links on the path and resolving all '..' and '.' path segments.

dart-io.Link.resolveSymbolicLinksSync uses the operating system's native filesystem api to resolve the path, using the realpath function on linux and Mac OS, and the GetFinalPathNameByHandle function on Windows. If the path does not point to an existing file system object, dart-io.Link.resolveSymbolicLinksSync throws a FileSystemException.

On Windows, symbolic links are resolved to their target before applying a '..' that follows, and on other platforms, the '..' is applied to the symbolic link without resolving it. The second behavior can be emulated on Windows by processing any '..' segments before calling dart-io.Link.resolveSymbolicLinks. One way of doing this is with the URI class: :new Uri.parse('.').resolveUri(new Uri.file(input)).toFilePath();, since resolve removes '..' segments.

rename.name: rename
rename.comment:
Renames this link. Returns a Future<Link> that completes with a dart-io.Link instance for the renamed link.

If dart-io.Link.rename.newPath identifies an existing link, that link is replaced. If dart-io.Link.rename.newPath identifies an existing file or directory, the operation fails and the future completes with an exception.

renameSync.name: renameSync
renameSync.comment:
Synchronously renames this link. Returns a dart-io.Link instance for the renamed link.

If dart-io.Link.renameSync.newPath identifies an existing link, that link is replaced. If dart-io.Link.renameSync.newPath identifies an existing file or directory the operation fails and an exception is thrown.

target.name: target
target.comment:
Gets the target of the link. Returns a future that completes with the path to the target.

If the returned target is a relative path, it is relative to the directory containing the link.

If the link does not exist, or is not a link, the future completes with a FileSystemException.

targetSync.name: targetSync
targetSync.comment:
Synchronously gets the target of the link. Returns the path to the target.

If the returned target is a relative path, it is relative to the directory containing the link.

If the link does not exist, or is not a link, throws a FileSystemException.

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides dart-io.Link.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

isAbsolute.name: isAbsolute
isAbsolute.comment:
Returns a dart-core.bool indicating whether this object's path is absolute.

On Windows, a path is absolute if it starts with \\ or a drive letter between a and z (upper or lower case) followed by :\ or :/. On non-Windows, a path is absolute if it starts with /.

absolute.name: absolute
absolute.comment:
Returns a dart-io.FileSystemEntity whose path is the absolute path to this. The type of the returned instance is the type of this.

The absolute path is computed by prefixing a relative path with the current working directory, and returning an absolute path unchanged.

parent.name: parent
parent.comment: The directory containing this. If this is a root directory, returns this.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and dart-io.Link.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the dart-io.Link.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
dart-io.Link.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to dart-io.Link.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If dart-io.Link.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of dart-io.Link.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.

exists.name: exists
exists.comment:
Checks whether the file system entity with this path exists. Returns a Future<bool> that completes with the result.

Since FileSystemEntity is abstract, every FileSystemEntity object is actually an instance of one of the subclasses dart-io.File, dart-io.Directory, and dart-io.Link. Calling dart-io.Link.exists on an instance of one of these subclasses checks whether the object exists in the file system object exists and is of the correct type (file, directory, or link). To check whether a path points to an object on the file system, regardless of the object's type, use the dart-io.FileSystemEntity.type static method.

existsSync.name: existsSync
existsSync.comment:
Synchronously checks whether the file system entity with this path exists.

Since FileSystemEntity is abstract, every FileSystemEntity object is actually an instance of one of the subclasses dart-io.File, dart-io.Directory, and dart-io.Link. Calling dart-io.Link.existsSync on an instance of one of these subclasses checks whether the object exists in the file system object exists and is of the correct type (file, directory, or link). To check whether a path points to an object on the file system, regardless of the object's type, use the dart-io.FileSystemEntity.typeSync static method.

rename.name: rename
rename.comment:
Renames this file system entity. Returns a Future<FileSystemEntity> that completes with a dart-io.FileSystemEntity instance for the renamed file system entity.

If dart-io.Link.rename.newPath identifies an existing entity of the same type, that entity is replaced. If dart-io.Link.rename.newPath identifies an existing entity of a different type, the operation fails and the future completes with an exception.

renameSync.name: renameSync
renameSync.comment:
Synchronously renames this file system entity. Returns a dart-io.FileSystemEntity instance for the renamed entity.

If dart-io.Link.renameSync.newPath identifies an existing entity of the same type, that entity is replaced. If dart-io.Link.renameSync.newPath identifies an existing entity of a different type, the operation fails and an exception is thrown.

resolveSymbolicLinks.name: resolveSymbolicLinks
resolveSymbolicLinks.comment:
Resolves the path of a file system object relative to the current working directory, resolving all symbolic links on the path and resolving all '..' and '.' path segments. dart-io.Link.resolveSymbolicLinks returns a Future<String>

dart-io.Link.resolveSymbolicLinks uses the operating system's native filesystem api to resolve the path, using the realpath function on linux and Mac OS, and the GetFinalPathNameByHandle function on Windows. If the path does not point to an existing file system object, dart-io.Link.resolveSymbolicLinks completes the returned Future with an FileSystemException.

On Windows, symbolic links are resolved to their target before applying a '..' that follows, and on other platforms, the '..' is applied to the symbolic link without resolving it. The second behavior can be emulated on Windows by processing any '..' segments before calling dart-io.Link.resolveSymbolicLinks. One way of doing this is with the URI class: :new Uri.parse('.').resolveUri(new Uri.file(input)).toFilePath();, since resolve removes '..' segments.

resolveSymbolicLinksSync.name: resolveSymbolicLinksSync
resolveSymbolicLinksSync.comment:
Resolves the path of a file system object relative to the current working directory, resolving all symbolic links on the path and resolving all '..' and '.' path segments.

dart-io.Link.resolveSymbolicLinksSync uses the operating system's native filesystem api to resolve the path, using the realpath function on linux and Mac OS, and the GetFinalPathNameByHandle function on Windows. If the path does not point to an existing file system object, dart-io.Link.resolveSymbolicLinksSync throws a FileSystemException.

On Windows, symbolic links are resolved to their target before applying a '..' that follows, and on other platforms, the '..' is applied to the symbolic link without resolving it. The second behavior can be emulated on Windows by processing any '..' segments before calling dart-io.Link.resolveSymbolicLinks. One way of doing this is with the URI class: :new Uri.parse('.').resolveUri(new Uri.file(input)).toFilePath();, since resolve removes '..' segments.

stat.name: stat
stat.comment:
Calls the operating system's stat() function on the dart-io.Link.path of this dart-io.FileSystemEntity. Identical to FileStat.stat(this.path).

Returns a Future<FileStat> object containing the data returned by stat().

If the call fails, completes the future with a dart-io.FileStat object with .type set to FileSystemEntityType.NOT_FOUND and the other fields invalid.

statSync.name: statSync
statSync.comment:
Synchronously calls the operating system's stat() function on the dart-io.Link.path of this dart-io.FileSystemEntity. Identical to FileStat.statSync(this.path).

Returns a dart-io.FileStat object containing the data returned by stat().

If the call fails, returns a dart-io.FileStat object with .type set to FileSystemEntityType.NOT_FOUND and the other fields invalid.

delete.name: delete
delete.comment:
Deletes this dart-io.FileSystemEntity.

If the dart-io.FileSystemEntity is a directory, and if dart-io.Link.delete.recursive is false, the directory must be empty. Otherwise, if dart-io.Link.delete.recursive is true, the directory and all sub-directories and files in the directories are deleted. Links are not followed when deleting recursively. Only the link is deleted, not its target.

If dart-io.Link.delete.recursive is true, the dart-io.FileSystemEntity is deleted even if the type of the dart-io.FileSystemEntity doesn't match the content of the file system. This behavior allows dart-io.Link.delete to be used to unconditionally delete any file system object.

Returns a Future<FileSystemEntity> that completes with this dart-io.FileSystemEntity when the deletion is done. If the dart-io.FileSystemEntity cannot be deleted, the future completes with an exception.

deleteSync.name: deleteSync
deleteSync.comment:
Synchronously deletes this dart-io.FileSystemEntity.

If the dart-io.FileSystemEntity is a directory, and if dart-io.Link.deleteSync.recursive is false, the directory must be empty. Otherwise, if dart-io.Link.deleteSync.recursive is true, the directory and all sub-directories and files in the directories are deleted. Links are not followed when deleting recursively. Only the link is deleted, not its target.

If dart-io.Link.deleteSync.recursive is true, the dart-io.FileSystemEntity is deleted even if the type of the dart-io.FileSystemEntity doesn't match the content of the file system. This behavior allows dart-io.Link.deleteSync to be used to unconditionally delete any file system object.

Throws an exception if the dart-io.FileSystemEntity cannot be deleted.

watch.name: watch
watch.comment:
Start watching the dart-io.FileSystemEntity for changes.

The implementation uses platform-dependent event-based APIs for receiving file-system notifications, thus behavior depends on the platform.

  • Windows: Uses ReadDirectoryChangesW. The implementation only supports watching directories. Recursive watching is supported.

  • Linux: Uses inotify. The implementation supports watching both files and directories. Recursive watching is not supported. Note: When watching files directly, delete events might not happen as expected.

  • Mac OS: Uses FSEvents. The implementation supports watching both files and directories. Recursive watching is supported.

The system will start listening for events once the returned dart-async.Stream is being listened to, not when the call to dart-io.Link.watch is issued.

The returned value is an endless broadcast dart-async.Stream, that only stops when one of the following happends:

  • The dart-async.Stream is canceled, e.g. by calling cancel on the dart-async.StreamSubscription.

  • The dart-io.FileSystemEntity being watches, is deleted.

Use events to specify what events to listen for. The constants in dart-io.FileSystemEvent can be or'ed together to mix events. Default is dart-io.FileSystemEvent.ALL.
